sect1.title: CASE 46
sect1.para: The patient was a 29-year-old male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension and migraine headaches. Three months previously, he was seen in the emergency department (ED) with what was diagnosed by physical examination as bacterial gingivitis. During this encounter, the ED physician suggested that the patient be tested for HIV. He declined.

listitem.para: 1. Why do you think that the ED physician suggested that the patient be tested for HIV?
2. What are some reasons that an individual would refuse an HIV test?
3. Three days prior to admission, the patient was seen in the ED with a headache but left without seeing a care provider. What infections are associated with headaches?

4. On the day of admission, a family member brought the patient to the ED. He presented with altered mental status, including confusion, inability to follow commands, and speech that was difficult to understand. He was not able to cooperate with a physical examination. His vital signs at the time of his physical examination were blood pressure (BP), 159/111 mm Hg; heart rate, 78 beats/minute; and respiratory rate, 22 breaths/minute. How was his previous ED visit 3 days earlier associated with his current ED visit?

sect1.para: He was afebrile and his white blood cell count was within normal limits. His family and social history given by a family member was unremarkable. Because of his altered mental status, a lumbar puncture was performed. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cell count was 2 cells/μl with 82% lymphocytes, CSF protein of 48 mg/dl, and CSF glucose within normal limits. The Gram stain of CSF is shown in Fig. 46.1.

listitem.para: 5. What is CSF?

figure.title: Figure 46.1 Gram stain of patient’s CSF. From author’s collection. Magnification, ×1,000.

textobject.para: A microscopic photograph showing numerous round, dark-colored bacterial cells dispersed across a light background, with some forming clusters.

listitem.para: 6. Was his CSF cell count normal or abnormal? What about his CSF protein?
7. Was his CSF Gram stain normal or abnormal? What is seen in the Gram stain?
8. What rapid test (10 minutes) can be done to confirm the Gram stain findings? What is the value of doing this test?
9. How do you explain the CSF cell count and protein in the setting of the patient’s Gram stain result?

sect1.para: When the Gram stain result was available, the physician ordered the following tests: HIV serology, HIV viral load, and CD4 count.

listitem.para: 10. Briefly explain how each of these tests is done and what you think was the result of each of these tests.

sect1.para: This patient was positive by the confirmatory test for HIV-1 antibodies, his viral load at admission was >200,000 copies/ml, which is extremely high, and his CD4 count was <10 cells/μl.

listitem.para: 11. The next day, CSF culture revealed the organism seen in Fig. 46.2. Does the culture result confirm your Gram stain findings?

12. Over the next 2 days, the patient had two seizures and developed sepsis with bradycardia and a BP of 90/50 mm Hg despite three vasopressors. He had a cardiac arrest from which he could not be revived. How do you think that this patient became infected with this organism? Describe the pathogenesis of his infection, including its major virulence factor.
13. The infectious disease (ID) consultant recommended that the patient not receive antiretroviral therapy despite a very high viral load and low CD4 count. What was the consultant’s concern?
14. What opportunities were missed that might have saved this patient’s life?

figure.title: Figure 46.2 Colony morphology of growth on a sheep blood agar plate inoculated with the patient’s CSF. From author’s collection.

textobject.para: A photograph shows red agar containing numerous small, round, white bacterial colonies growing on its surface.

sect1.para: 1. The CDC recommends that everyone between 13 and 64 years of age know their HIV status by being tested (1). This is likely the reason the physician considered doing HIV testing in this patient. There is nothing in the literature to link bacterial gingivitis with HIV infections.
2. Here are some of the reasons reported for refusing an HIV test (2):

listitem.para: Recent negative test
Fear of having HIV and not wanting to know
Does not “feel” sick
Has not done anything that would expose them to HIV
Does not want others to know their HIV status
Concerns about exposing sexual practices
Potential strain on a relationship

sect1.para: 3. Inflammation caused by many infections may be associated with headaches; however, infections of the central nervous system, such as encephalitis and meningitis, associated with increased intracranial pressure almost always have headache as a symptom of disease.
4. Rapid progression of a headache to severe alteration in mental status with compensatory hypertension is consistent with an acute intracranial process caused by either a stroke or infection.
5. CSF is a fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord and acts to cushion these structures against trauma.

6. Both the CSF cell count and protein were within normal limits for the institution where he received care. Although the CSF protein was slightly elevated, it would not be considered abnormal by most clinicians based on the other normal CSF findings.

7. CSF is normally sterile, so organisms should never be present there. The large, round structures that are predominantly Gram positive are yeast cells surrounded by a polysaccharide capsule. The round morphology with narrow based budding is most consistent with the yeast Cryptococcus neoformans, the primary agent of fungal meningitis. C. neoformans can be of varying sizes but is significantly larger than bacteria. Another species of Cryptococcus, C. gatti is now recognized as an infrequent cause of fungal meningitis primarily in areas with warm wet climates associated with eucalyptus trees. In the United States and Canada, cases have been seen primarily in the Pacific Northwest or in those who have recently traveled there. Unlike C. neoformans, it can cause meningitis in immunocompetent individuals (3).

8. The reddish rim around the yeast cell is consistent with a capsule. The capsule that surrounds the cell and protects it from phagocytosis is composed of a polysaccharide (glucuronoxylomannan) specific to C. neoformans. It can be detected using antibody specific for it in a lateral flow antigen (C. neoformans capsular polysaccharide) detection test (4). This test takes 10 minutes to perform and is highly sensitive (99%) and specific (98%). It has replaced India ink microscopic examination of CSF as a rapid means to identify cryptococci. India ink is a negative stain, meaning the background is stained but not the organism. The organism is surrounded by a clear halo, which is due to the capsular polysaccharide not taking up the stain. It has a sensitivity of only 86% and requires expert microscopic skills since white blood cells can be confused with cryptococci because of similarities in size and morphology.

9. A young adult male who has evidence of cryptococcal meningitis has a high likelihood of having advanced HIV disease (5). One of the features of advanced HIV disease is a poor or absent cell-mediated immune response. Cell-mediated immunity is essential for protection against fungal pathogens. Because an individual with a low CD4 count (see answer to question 10 for more details) cannot mount a cell-mediated response to this organism, the white cell count and protein may appear “normal.” In patients with a functioning immune system, we would expect to see an elevated white blood cell count in the CSF (usually in the range of 100 to 500 cells/μl with a predominance of lymphocytes) and elevated protein due in part to the immune response to the organisms.

10.The CDC recommends a fourth-generation enzyme immunoassay (EIA) that detects antibodies to both HIV-1 and HIV-2 and p 24 antigen(6). If the initial EIA test is positive, a confirmatory test is done for HIV-1 and -2 antibodies. If these are both negative, an HIV viral load assay is done to confirm the p 24 antigen part of the assay (seecase 62 for further discussion).
HIV viral load is determined by a quantitative nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT). It is a measure of the severity of infection.

CD4+ T helper lymphocytes play a central role in cell-mediated immunity and are measured using a technique called flow cytometry(7). Normal CD4 counts are between 500 and 1,500 cells/μl. Patients who have <200 cells/μl are defined as having advanced HIV disease. As the number of CD4 cells declines below 200 cells/μl toward 0, HIV-infected individuals are at an ever-increasing risk for a variety of opportunistic infections, including (8):

listitem.para: C. neoformans meningitis
Cytomegalovirus pneumonia and retinitis
Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
Disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection
Pulmonary and disseminated Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection
Candida esophagitis
Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis
Human papillomavirus-associated malignancies
Kaposi’s sarcoma associated with human herpesvirus 8
Epstein-Barr virus-associated malignancies
Cryptosporidium enteritis

sect1.para: 11. Yes. C. neoformans has a colony morphology similar to that of bacteria with a very mucoid appearance. A Gram stain of the colony could be used to confirm that the organism is a round encapsulated yeast with narrow based budding. Further testing, such as matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) could be done to confirm the identity of the organism as C. neoformans. It is important to note that Cryptococcus is intrinsically resistant to echinocandin antifungals, like micafungin, which are widely used to treat most yeast infections. It is therefore critical that clinicians be rapidly alerted to this diagnosis.

12. C. neoformans is ubiquitous in nature, widely distributed in soil (7). It is frequently found in areas with high concentrations of birds because bird guano contains nutrients that enhance its growth. Individuals become infected by breathing in dehydrated yeast cells or spores from the environment. Its capsule allows it to initially evade phagocytosis, but T-cell-mediated granuloma formation, where the cryptococcal cells are walled off in the lung tissue, limits disease progression. Infected immunocompetent patients rarely have symptoms, and when they do, they are mild and do not require medical care. In individuals with advanced HIV disease, the reduction or absence of cell-mediated immunity allows the encapsulated yeasts to multiply and penetrate into the bloodstream from the lung, causing fungemia. In individuals with very low CD4 cell counts, as was seen in this patient, this organism may then cross the blood-brain barrier and cause meningitis.

13. A potential complication of antiretroviral therapy in patients with advanced HIV disease who develop cryptococcal meningitis is immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, or IRIS (9). In IRIS, as the CD4 count increases during antiretroviral therapy, the patient can mount an inflammatory response to, in this case, cryptococcal antigens. This inflammation can cause brain edema. In severe episodes of IRIS, this edema can result in brain herniation and death. Naïve patients with advanced HIV disease (those who have not received antiretroviral therapy) and cryptococcal meningitis should first be treated for their fungal infection to reduce organism burden and subsequently treated for HIV. When naïve HIV-infected patients were treated concordantly with antifungal and antiretroviral therapies, they had a 15% higher mortality (9). The timing of when to institute antiretroviral therapy in HIV-infected patients being treated for cryptococcal meningitis is multifactorial and beyond the scope of this discussion.

14. A patient who has HIV diagnosed at presentation for a serious or life-threatening opportunistic infection such as cryptococcal meningitis is said to have an AIDS-defining condition or advanced HIV disease (10).
There were two missed opportunities that might have allowed the survival of the patient.

When the patient was seen 3 months prior to his final admission, he was offered but refused HIV testing. The reasons individuals refuse HIV testing, which is recommended by the CDC for everyone between 13 and 64 years of age, are complex. Several are listed inanswer 2. If it was established at his initial visit that he was HIV positive, he could have begun receiving care, started antiretroviral therapy, and possibly avoided becoming infected with Cryptococcus.

The second opportunity was when he came to the ED 3 days prior to his admission and left without being seen. In all likelihood, he was at an earlier stage of cryptococcal meningitis. At that point antifungal therapy might have been curative.

listitem.para: The CDC recommends that everyone between 13 and 64 years of age know their HIV status and be tested for HIV. Individuals who engage in activities that carry a high risk of HIV infection—including but not limited to men who have sex with men, anyone with a history of a sexually transmitted disease, individuals with multiple sexual partners, and individuals who share needles—should be tested annually. This testing can be anonymous if the individual prefers.
The CDC has a specific testing algorithm for diagnosis of HIV (see Fig. 46.3 and reference 11 for further details; see also case 62).

figure.title: Figure 46.3 CDC HIV testing algorithm. See reference 11 for further details.

textobject.para: A flowchart outlining the recommended laboratory HIV testing algorithm for serum or plasma specimens, starting with HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody immunoassay, followed by differentiation immunoassays to determine HIV-1 or HIV-2 infection, with results indicating positive, negative, or indeterminate outcomes, and including confirmatory tests such as NAT.

listitem.para: People with advanced HIV disease by definition have <200 CD4+ T cells per μl. As CD4 counts fall toward 0, the likelihood of invasive disease increases. Some of the more common infections seen in people with advanced HIV disease include:
C. neoformans meningitis
Cytomegalovirus pneumonia and retinitis
P. jirovecii pneumonia
Disseminated M. avium complex infection
Pulmonary and disseminated M. tuberculosis infection
Candida esophagitis
T. gondii encephalitis
Human papillomavirus-associated malignancies
Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated with human herpesvirus 8
Epstein-Barr virus-associated malignancies
Cryptosporidium enteritis
C. neoformans is an encapsulated, round yeast that is ubiquitous in nature. Its key virulence factor is its antiphagocytic polysaccharide capsule.

In immunocompetent individuals,C. neoformans most frequently causes asymptomatic pulmonary infection in which isolated pulmonary granulomas may form. In immunosuppressed individuals, including those with advanced HIV disease, disseminated infections such as fungemia with skin lesions and meningitis may occur.

In individuals who have cryptococcal meningitis as an advanced HIV disease-defining condition, initiation of antiretroviral therapy is delayed because of concerns for IRIS. As the immune system “recovers” during antiretroviral therapy, individuals may develop a severe inflammatory response to cryptococcal antigens in the central nervous system, which may lead to brain edema and, in its most severe manifestations, herniation and death. The initiation of antiretroviral therapy following resolution of cryptococcal meningitis in patients with advanced HIV disease is complex.
